f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:54): Hixie, for input type=tel, the spec says "User agents may change the punctuation of values that the user enters." - Does that affect the submitted value, or just the way in which the number is rendered?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:56): in my experience, many sites don't accept any punctuation in phone numbers.
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (17:56): "values" points to the value concept which means afaict that it affects the submission
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:57): I guess, if they use type=tel, then hopefully they will fix their back end too
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (17:57): it would be nicer if type=tel specified some canonicalized value for submission
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:58): I don't think that's really possible given the wide variety of formats used for phone numbers around the world
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:58): and even formats for phone numbers in the same country, depending on whether they're land line, mobile, free call or premium rate numbers
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (17:58): international dialing is possible
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (17:59): surely canonicalizing phone numbers is possible too then
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:59): The canonical format could be created with s/[^0-9]//g
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:59): but that doesn't help when silly Americans use letters instead of numbers in their phone numbers
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:59): wonders if other nationalities do that too
467f6d43402c6573237052cefcc252db (18:00): though some phone numbers are bound by country
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:00): Also that wouldn't work when people write "+44 (0)1234 567890"

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:28): The pattern attribute probably shouldn't be allowed to apply to type=tel given that browsers are allowed to automatically adjust the punctuation
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:28): is quite concerned at the idea of browsers automatically adjusting punctuation
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:29): I'm a little concerned about it. But it's what my phone does when I enter a number into the address book
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:29): and, for the most part, it seems to apply country specific formatting conventions fairly reliably
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:30): Is there some list of the use cases for entering phone numbers?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:30): Many registration forms, alas
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:30): I'm not sure how browsers will be able to tell what punctuation is required. Browsers will need to be compatible but there is no spec

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:30): Here's a use case: A site wishes to harvest phone numbers for use by telemarketers, and needs a convenient way for users to quickly and easily enter their phone number

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:30): like, is it for e.g. address books where you want a nice human-readable (and not machine-readable) format, and it's basically plain text but you want to stop people typing in garbage?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:31): or is it for machine-readable numbers so a machine can automatically phone you, without any human involvement?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:32): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Probably both
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:32): In the former case I guess you'd want to allow numbers like "01234 567890 (switchboard; ask for John Smith)" too

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:32): I think the use case is because it allows for integration with the user's address book, and in mobile browsers with touch screens, focussing the control gives a keypad designed for entering numbers, rather than a normal text entry keypad
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:32): (and quick access to tehir contacts list)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:32): Ah, I guess the autofill case is independent of any validation or canonicalisation
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:33): s/autofill/fancy input method/

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:33): I don't think we can stop people typing in garbage, because the phone number conventions use a wide variety of strange punctuation characters, inluding + ( ) # , . (space) and many others
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:33): It is just a hint to a UA; the server has to be able to deal with the possibility of a garbale value anyway
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:34): So having UAs mung the actual value seems bad
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:35): for a normal desktop browser, yes.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:35): but for a user with a browser on a mobile phone, it could be convenient

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:36): so that the number gets formatted nicely for easier reading, without the user having to manually enter characters that aren't so easy to type on a mobile keypad

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:37): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: That seems to be something that is between the UA and the user if they want to have a special UI for entering numbers that pretty prints the result before updating the control
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:38): Not really something that should be in the spec
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (18:38): the spec just says it's permitted, not that it's required
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:39): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: The spec doesn't say every time that a UA is permitted to innovate the UI
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:39): The spec normatively states that it's permitted, which seems unusual for UI issues
